summary: Pistachio Disguisey (Dana Carvey), a genial waiter at his father Frabbrizio's (James Brolin) Italian restaurant, possesses an uncanny knack for mimicry. What he doesn't know is that his talent is genetic, and that he is the descendent of a long line of "Masters of Disguise," all of whom have inherited the secret family gift known as Energico. Initially, Pistachio is a klutz, but little by little, he learns to harness his inherited power, and sallies forth to utilize Energico to its fullest.

I was aware of The Master of Disguise's dubious reputation, and after finally seeing it after years of avoiding it I agree that its reputation doesn't lie. In my opinion, this movie is very poor. Some of the make-up is diverting on a mild level, but that is it. The editing feels cheap and slip-shod, the colours feel diluted and to be honest gave me a headache and the sets and effects are flat. The humour is also of quite a crude kind, including the idea of the villain breaking wind when he laughs, you can tell these are not the ideas of comedy geniuses. The direction is sorely lacking and Dana Carvey clearly looks embarrassed playing a character that is not so easy to relate to, though in fairness none of the characters are that well written at all. The worst parts of The Master of Disguise though are the screenplay which is very lame, the plot which is barely coherent and the mugging which gets increasingly desperate. In conclusion, very poor. 1/10 Bethany Cox

So my thoughts on The Master of Disguise are this. 

One of the things I did like are some of the set designs. I actually thought those were very stylish. Seeing as how a production designer directed this film, that's to be expected.

My trip back through this film, however, begins with an awkward song over the opening credits and a mystical song over the introduction being interrupted by a cheesy pop song. Oh, and the opening chase is awkward as well.

One of the things that can and probably will irritate you a lot are all the accents and attempts at weird, childish speaking that NOBODY would speak like in real life.

Oh, yeah, one of the gags in this film is giant asses. I'm not particularly amused by it. And there's a kid who doesn't laugh to a Shrek joke. Pretty much sums this film up.

One of the things this movie does is echoing and saying things over and over again. This film really does have ADD, and for someone who is autistic, I kind of find it insulting.

Now we have Brent Spiner. He's the only character in this entire film who does not speak in a funny voice, which has gotten unfunny rather quickly. He actually does a better job than anyone else in the movie.

The British imitation in the mansion really is the only disguise that has any sort of tolerability.

What's the point of saying you're a pre-recorded hologram. It doesn't really work.

One of the things that disappoints me about this film is there was a hell of a lot of potential for a movie and franchise with this disguise theme. But it was in the wrong hands and was not used well. At. All. It just feels childish. Anything that is not childish, is either awkward, mean-spirited, or otherwise boring. I can see the style, but director Blake cannot direct and Dana Carvey did not write anything worth a dollar. I really can't believe I saw this in theaters. The only person in this entire film who has any sort of viability is Brent Spiner. He speaks normally and is the only person or thing who is not annoying. I think one of the reasons is because he's not trying to be deliberately funny. If this film is any indication, trying to be deliberately funny never works. Adam Sandler keeps doing it. It hasn't worked once.

While some great movies are considered love letters to certain genres (like "The Empire Strikes Back" to Sci Fi and "Monty Python and the Holy Grail" to comedy) this movie is a death threat to the good name of comedy at almost every turn.  I could almost write a book on how mercilessly this film destroys the unwritten yet generally agreed upon rules of comedy as well as drama.  

I begin by stating that I first saw this movie at a friend's house when I was about 8-10 years old.  Very young and very impressionable.  This was at a time my favorite TV show was "Spongebob Squarepants" and I laughed at almost anything so I was prepared for a good time.  Sadly, the movie offered me no laughs and was a complete waste of my time.  The movie is only about 72 minutes but it felt as long as "Return of the King" (the movie) and it was as boring as listening to the book's appendices.

When it comes to breaking the rules of comedy, Dana Carvey's character is named Pistachiao Disguisey.  Beyond the stupid character name, Carvey makes incredibly stupid faces and impressions in an attempt to make the character come to life.  It violates comedy because its not a character acting stupid and silly that's funny, it's the situations that the character is in and how the character reacts to it that is (it's usually a negative reaction because comedy is based on some form of either physical or emotional pain).  

Like I said before, I could go on about how dreadful this but I'll just sum up and say that the comedy is severely lacking, the plot makes no sense, and the movie as a whole is just a miserably failed attempt to capitalize on Dana Carvey's talent for mimicry.

When you're one of the hottest players on the long-running sketch program "Saturday Night Live", the jump to feature films is all but assured. For Dana Carvey, life after the show was rosy with the first two "Wayne's World" pictures hitting it big at the box office. But at the turn of the century, the laughs had all but dried up and we're left with "The Master of Disguise", a kids movie that is too dumb to be enjoyed even by most children.

It has rightfully earned its reputation as one of the worst comedies of all time, a dismal film that leaves you questioning everyone involved with the project. Carvey is clearly a talented comedian and impressionist, so producer Adam Sandler and the star came up with the thinnest of plots and pretty much turned him loose. 

The end result is a completely disastrous, laugh-free dud of epic proportions, a kids movie that inexplicably throws in adult references in everything from "Jaws" to "Scarface" to "The Exorcist", and none of it is amusing. It follows the model of most Sandler movies, giving Carvey a hot love interest who for some reason finds this irritating buffoon irresistible. It's a tired plot device that is almost as aggravating as the lead performance.

The picture is mercifully short, at a brief 72 minutes with the actors continually popping up in the end credits like an annoying house guest who refuses to leave. It may seem like a blessing, as in reality "The Master of Disguise" feels like a never-ending experience. It wears out its welcome very early on.

Dana Carvey's comedic "skills" are so awful that they're a pale imitation of charming masterful Italian actor Roberto Benigni,, which is ironic because the Golden Raspberry award for Worst Actor of 2002 went to Roberto Benigni for his fine effort that was abused in post-production by editors, when clearly Dana Carvey is way more deserving. He looks like if Jim Carrey and Woody Allen had an unwanted child with the talents of a William Shatner wannabe or the aborted child of Popeye. His lack of talent was made clear in the utterly stupid "comedy" Trapped in Paradise, so why someone decided to give that guy the lead role in a film and a budget of $16 million is beyond me. Pauly Shore was never this bad no matter what people might say. 
The film is crap also, because its set up with childish material which is like if Spy Kids met Scary Movie, which makes it a terrible comedy and half-assed spoof at the same time. But again, that can be brought back to Dana Carvey for writing the disastrous script that he attempted to work with for a gruelling 77 minutes, and partially for Perry Andelin Blake's inexperienced direction and inability to realise the horrendous quality of the material he is working with.
There was one moment in The Master of Disguise that I laughed, and it was because the scene was a paradigm of how utterly stupid this disastrous waste of $16 million was. The best thing it achieved in any area was killing Dana Carvey's career as he didn't appear in a film again after it until the Golden Raspberry Award sweeper Jack & Jill in 2011. He can stick to being a cameo and a joke, but not a film star. Not a film star.

The Master Of Disguise is a hideous and brutally unfunny comedy. Within the first few minutes, I was already groaning because of how tiresome and repetitive the jokes were. The film already hits a sour note with its poorly conceived premise that was given virtually no thought whatsoever. Throw in what must be one of cinematic history's most annoying characters and you have a stunning achievement in failure. Every joke falls flat, the main character is annoying as fuck, the story is utterly dreadful and confusing, the disguises are awful, there are pointless references to actual GOOD films (Scarface, Jaws, etc.), and every other aspect of its creation is incompetent from top to bottom. The Master Of Disguise is easily one of the worst comedies I've ever seen and I have no idea why anyone thought it was a good idea. Even by the standards of Happy Madison Productions, this film is absolute garbage! If you enjoy good comedies, you should avoid this film at all costs.

Pre-teens will probably have fun with "The Master of Disguise" but for everyone else it's a near-unwatchable and embarrassing experience. The humour in the film is what really kills it and makes it torturous to watch. It's not that there aren't any jokes that work(when you throw this many jokes at the screen there's got to be at least one or two things that stick) but you'll feel ashamed of yourself for giving even a second of laughter to this train wreck. The reason why this is firmly a "kids only movie" is because so many of the jokes are so incredibly juvenile. The name of our protagonist is "Pistachio Disguisey". Did that make you laugh? Because that's one of the first jokes we get. His name is "Disguisey" because he is going to be a master of disguise, get it? His character is defined by another series of jokes where we learn that he likes women with big butts. This preference is in the film so we can have jokes about big butts. No, there's nothing more to it than that, the fact that he likes big butts is the joke. He's also a bumbling idiot that's barely able to wait tables, speaks in broken English (although no one else in the family does) but in an attempt to make you like the director makes sure to include several scenes showing that he's a nice guy. The fact that he is nice is only in the film so you can have villains to contrast with his personality and because if it wasn't for the forced redemption scenes you would be cheering how him to get brutally murdered within a few minutes of meeting him.

Moving on from "Pistachio", we get an incredibly bland sidekick named "Jennifer" played by Jennifer Esposito. She is in the movie for two reasons: first so we can have a love plot at the end of the film (a cherry on top of the sundae when our hero defeats the villain) and second so we can showcase how nice "Pistachio" is when he confronts her boyfriend, a guy that's such a transparent jerk the movie only pretends he genuinely likes "Jennifer" for about 30 seconds before exposing him as a child-hating, lying and cheating bully. His character is taken straight out of a cartoon and is included because there is no way you would otherwise believe that the 29-year-old woman would fall in love with Dana Carvey, who was 47 when the movie was made. That's right, the man is nearly fifty but he is playing a na√Øve, bumbling waiter that is still living with his parents. "Jennifer" has a son too, who is introduced early in the film and completely disappears until the very end and is only included so "Pistachio" can befriend him (while her boyfriend reveals that he hates children) but it seems incredibly creepy for the two to be friends considering the age difference. Our villainous mastermind is Devlin Bowman (played by Brent Spiner), who is focused not on taking over the world, but on stealing every valuable artifact in existence. His character might have felt like a genuine threat if it wasn't for the fact that he has an embarrassing gas problem to make the kiddies laugh.

So where do our abysmal characters land themselves? In a plot that is so thin it lasts 70 minutes (that's right, the short 80 minute running time is padded out with 10 minutes of credits and out-takes at the end) and is taken straight out of every generic spy film story ever made. The plot is simply an excuse for Dana Carvey to disguise himself in a series of outrageous characters including a horny old lady, "Tony Montoya" from "Scarface" (because children will delight in the pop culture reference?), a British Nerd, a suave secret agent, a racist stereotype of an indian snake-charmer, a patch of grass with cow dung for a face and a man covered in cherries (in a sequence that makes absolutely no sense). Although the makeup is pretty convincing, the film makes the crucial mistake of casting some celebrities in the film as "Pistachop's" father in disguise, which completely ruins one of the final jokes of the film: Dana Carvey disguised as President George W. Bush. The jokes include such gems as Dana Carvey commenting on the size of tiny appetizer wieners and nuts, outrageous dancing, references to jaws, "Pistachio" getting beaten up by a training dummy and a hologram that can interact with people and reacts to the "hilarious" events going on around it  (despite the fact the movie explicitly explains to us that It's pre-recorded). The only thing that works in the movie is the technical aspect. The props, sets and costumes look good but everything else is total trash. Avoid "The Master of Disguise" unless your maturity level is on par with a 12-year-old and even then, just rent or go see a better movie. (Dvd, May 10, 2013)

Hey, dummies - this movie was made for kids.  Dana Carvey himself stated that the movie was essentially made to be a kids' movie. The folly of this movie is that it was a kids movie that wasn't clearly marketed as a kids movie, so people are judging it as a legit adult comedy. It's pointless for adults to review a kids movie and call it bad for being "immature" or "sophomoric."  Guess what? Kids love immature and sophomoric humor, so the movie does exactly what it set out to do - make kids laugh. Terrible film. Absolutely terrible. 

Dana Carvey cannot master anything, let alone act like he can. This is such a trainwreck of a film, i want to destroy the script writers for creating such a waste of time and money. The already iffy storyline is destroyed by the unfunny antics of Dana Carvey and a band of untalented actors and actresses. 

The plot is hairbrained mush, something about a guy named very ridiculously Pistachio Disguisey (whoever wrote this screenplay and created the characters is a feaking moron) who happens to be on the roof of his parent's diner when he sees his father being kidnapped. After being dumped by his girlfriend for a more macho man.

Then instead of calling the police, he sits in his diner and thinks very calmly about what his next course of action should be. Then very suddenly his dog turns into his long-lost grandfather who has for some reason been disguised as the family dog for the past few years.

That isn't even the worst of it.

Grandfather then tells him that it is his destiny to catch his father's kidnapper by becoming the hero disguise-artist that his father and himself are. But first he needs rigorous training and a sidekick (the sidekick must also be a twenty-something hotie who has an adorably annoying young son who likes dogs).

The rest of the film soon becomes a blur of mistakes, terrible plotting, horrible scripting and lame-ass 'jokes'. The different disguises Dana Carvey portrays had potential, but this unbelievably shameful film is no place for the characters. Some argue that the Turtle Guy is the funniest character, but to me all of them are equally unfunny, and deliver extremely cliche lines for no reason. Worst scenes of all have to be the last few in which Carvey battles various ninjas, when Carvey tries to capture the criminal disguised as a superhero, the scene with the celebrations outside the Disguisey diner and when Carvey dresses as George W. Bush in order to finally catch the criminal. This last scene is for some reason placed during the end credits, despite being a pivotal point in the story, which is just another example of how idiotic

This film is so low-life that the bin it should be thrown into will spew if it is even touched by this ugly shit.

Dispite what critics and viewers alike have to say about it, The Master of Disguise is a hilarious and underrated comedy like no other movie before it. What more could you ask for? The disguises (both latex and CGI) are incredibly believeable, as are the many impersonations performed by Dana Carvey. The plot may seem very predictable, but if you're in the mood for a goofy film, this is the ticket to the land of laughter. Although The Master of Disguise does contain a few suggestive references, it only affects about 38% of the film. And best of all, even after seeing it about five and a half times up to date since 2009, this movie continues to make me smile as it parodies a number of older movies and various other gags without going too over the top (such as in the case of Austin Powers). Great cast, good humor!

Lots of bad impersonations (especially President George W. Bush) and slapstick humor. You may like it if you have that type of humor where you like very silly movies. Oh yeah, this was really stupid. Dana Carvey plays an incredibly annoying Italian guy with an even more annoying voice. Strangely, his accent sounds heavier than those of his two parents, played respectively by Edie McClurg and James Brolin, who I guess has decided to leave the Oscar nominations to son Josh. The movie basically consist of Carvey (with the help of his grandfather played by Harold Gould) trying to solve a mystery by jumping in and out of various characters, some better than others, while trying to woo his new assistant (Jennifer Esposito). She eventually becomes attracted to him because she is an extremely good-looking and intelligent woman while he is a not-so-good looking idiot, therefore the Laws of Comedy naturally come into effect (if it were not for them, family sitcoms and Judd Apatow would not exist). It also has running gag in which the main villain (Brent Spiner) farts every time he has an evil laugh even though it is not funny the first time it is done so there was really no point of repeating it. For the record, I am not totally opposed to fart jokes, but I think there is a right way of doing it and a wrong way of doing it; this falls into the latter category. I think you can make your own judgement from here.

To be honest, this review is not as harsh as it could be and for two reasons. First of all, I used to watch this type of stuff all the time when I was younger and have only recently become more mature about how I judge them (sort of). Secondly, I like Dana Carvey; he was great on "Saturday Night Live" as well as the "Wayne's World" movies (he recently recaptured that former glory with his appearance in the Funny or Die video "Presidential Reunion"). But ever since then, he seems to have been unable to find a project that is on par with his talents. At least this movie (tried to) play to his strength, which is character acting, as opposed to having him play straight like he did in the very unfunny film "Opportunity Knocks". At the moment, he is only working part-time in Hollywood anyway, but if he ever decides to be more active, I hope that he gets material that is of better quality than this film. Anyway, I do not recommend it unless you are bored.

Have some funny moments but overall fall short. Good they keep the movie runtime short. Movie begin with a hot woman running from a baddie Brent Spiner. The woman turn out to be master of disguise James Brolin. He is tired of this life and retreated. Now a restaurant boss with a dorky weird son Dana Carvey. Likes to wear underwear on his head and have mocking disease. He like woman with big bottom just like his mum (Edie McClurg) One woman rejected him. Dana make friend with a little boy. At night Josh and Edie got kidnap by Brent, who is back after jail time. Now he wants Josh to use his skills to help him obtain precious rare treasures or Edie will die. Dana is helpless and grandpa Harold Gould come to help him. He let him know their family history. Dana must learn the art of disguise. First funny scene begin, Dana make himself as indian snake charmer and the accent is really funny. James disguise as various people to get the items. Harold and Dana held a assistant interview but none make it. Then Jennifer Esposito, the hot mum of the boy came and got hire. Harold has to leave and Dana must learn the rest by himself. Looking for clues in the trash, Jennifer found a special made cigar and both go to the club for clues. Now they know who own the cigar. Dana disguise isn't really convincing. The boyfriend of Jennifer warn Dana to keep off from her. Brent hold a antique exhibition and Jennifer was invited to his private party. She urge Dana not to do any disguise. But he still go as Scarface Al Pacino, which is quite hilarious. Jennifer took some photos and was been suspected by Brent. Dana chase by henchmen and later disguise as Jaws Robert Shaw, really funny and convincing. Later on he disguise as some rich man and took away Jennifer. In the bar, they saw the boyfriend hooking up with the girl that rejected Dana. He give him a good knockout. Jennifer is impress by Dana and kiss him. James have stolen all the items and Brent is selling them on blackmarket ebay. He brainwash and disguise Josh as him and will kill him, making everyone think he is dead. The baddie kidnap Jennifer and Dana go to save her and James. Brent escape and Dana wear underwear on his head in order to wake James out of the brainwash. They go to Costa Rica to apprehend Brent. Jennifer and Dana got married.

You're missing the point. This movie accomplishes everything it set out to accomplish - to be as absurdly idiotic as possible. Like Napoleon Dynamite and Nacho Libre, the stupidity and awkwardness make the film what it is. It's a movie for quotes, if you know what I mean.

So just how dumb is this movie? Well just take a look at the plot, and you'll understand. I'm gonna guess you're probably like me and too lazy to actually read a detailed synopsis of it, so I'll explain it as simply as I can.

You've got the protagonist Pistachio, who is a awkward, mentally unstable little man looking to find his place in the world. His father and grandfather are professional Disguisey's. What's a Disguisey? Apparently someone that can morph into image of someone else. I don't really know if they use make-up or costumes or magic, I think it might be a mixture of all three- but who cares, thats what they do. Pistachio's parents are kidnapped and he's forced to learn the family trait of becoming a Disguisey in oder to get them back. 

Thats kind of a crude summary the of story, but hey. 

You've got to have a certain sense of humor to appreciate anything about this movie. Again, like Napoleon Dynamite, its "beauty" lies within its aimless stupidity, and awkwardness. The movie will leave you with memories not of crude jokes, and not of clever moments, but just quotes from incoherent scenes that you'll never get out of your head. Like it or not. And for that, I tip my hat to The Master of Disguise. I don't know what all you movie critics expected.
